reviews:
[h1]Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order[/h1]
I’ll be honest — I’ve never watched a single Star Wars movie before playing Jedi: Fallen Order. I barely knew who the Jedi even were. But despite that, this game completely drew me in and made me curious about the entire Star Wars universe.

From the start, Fallen Order impressed me with its cinematic storytelling and emotional depth. Cal Kestis’ journey felt relatable even without knowing the broader lore. The way the game slowly unveils his past and trauma kept me hooked, and the bond with BD-1? Instant favorite. The world-building, characters, and set pieces all felt so grand and immersive that I didn’t feel left out — instead, I felt pulled in.

Gameplay-wise, it’s a satisfying blend of exploration, puzzle-solving, and Souls-like combat. The lightsaber combat is incredibly fun, and using the Force powers just never gets old. The level design reminded me of Metroidvania-style games, with a real sense of reward for backtracking and unlocking new paths.

What’s wild is that by the end of the game, I actually wanted to watch the movies and learn more about this galaxy far, far away. Jedi: Fallen Order didn’t just entertain me — it turned me into a curious fan of a franchise I had ignored for years.

You don’t need to be a Star Wars expert to enjoy this game. It stands strong on its own, but it also opens the door to a much bigger universe. Now, I’ve got a watchlist full of Star Wars content — all thanks to one game.

Had to be in the right mood for it (which took years), but damn this game is actually fantastic. It may not have the deepest narrative, but it was enough to keep me invested. Thank u Shameless actor man you did a good job even though you kinda look like a baby

[b]Star Wars Jedi[/b] turned out to be one of those rare games that feels both overproduced and underwhelming. I can’t recommend it—not with a straight face, anyway. Admittedly, I’ve never been a devoted acolyte of the Star Wars mythos. My exposure is limited to the cultural osmosis of flickering television reruns: something about a Republic, a Darth Vader, and a family named Skywalker. That’s the extent of it.

The one genuine cultural gift Star Wars ever gave me was a detour into mythology: [i]Joseph Campbell’s The Hero with a Thousand Faces[/i], followed by [i]Christopher Vogler’s The Writer’s Journey[/i]. That was the real adventure—an anthropological deep-dive into narrative structure, far more engrossing than anything this game had to offer.

The game itself is fragmented across planets, each a showcase of [i]Unreal Engine’s[/i] visual might. Strands of the protagonist’s hair sway delicately in digital wind; gears shudder and slam with satisfying weight. Horizons stretch wide, offering a sense of scale. And yet, once the novelty fades, you're left with the bleak realization: this is a plodding platformer with questionable design choices. Tedious sequences repeat with minor variations, and the Metroidvania-inspired save system means every small triumph is undercut by the resurrection of previously defeated foes.

My patience ended somewhere on the outskirts of Eilram, when a hologram murmured something about a "fascinating tomb." It wasn’t. I quit shortly after, with the lingering sense that I had been wandering through a tomb myself—one built not for a Jedi, but for fun.

The first 40 minutes hinted at promise. After that, the narrative dissolved into a monotonous loop of wall-running, rope-swinging, and narrow corridors that induced more claustrophobia than cosmic wonder.

A beautifully rendered box, yes—but peel back the foil, and it’s not chocolate inside. Just licorice taffy. Sticky, bitter, and impossible to chew through.

-Combat is crisp.
-Story is compelling.
-Planets are looking gorgeous and fun to explore.
-BD-1 is goated.

Star Wars: Jedi Fallen Order is a phenomenal star wars game in years. Felt like it offered the right mix of adrenaline-pumping action and thoughtful exploration. With its amazing story, engaging platforming and combat mechanics, the game is a must-buy, despite the combat being too repetitive and some cringy dialogues on rare occasions which doesn't truly harm the experience as a whole, but still could have been better. By the way, I daresay that this game resembles what a modern Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast would have, if that combined the best elements of gameplay defining games, sensibly unified and supported by an amazing story which sets the rules without trying to be ground-breaking.

8/10
Lightsaber combat feels weighty, and the Metroidvania-level design is clever. The story is predictable but heartfelt. Survivor improved it, but this is still a must-play for SW fans.

Give me KOTOR or Jedi Outcast over this boring slog any day of the week.

From the start, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order proves that it's a proper Star Wars game. The story takes place between Episodes 3 and 4, and the main character is Padawan Cal Kestis, who hasn't completed his Jedi training and therefore doesn't have full control of the Force. He has to hide from the Empire and the Inquisitors, who are wiping out the remaining Jedi across the galaxy. Cal is teamed up with pilot Greez and former Jedi Cere, who has decided to renounce the Force. The team must find the Holocron, a list of all children who wield the Force, in order to restore the Jedi Order. The story is fairly simple, but it's all the more beautiful because it takes place in the Star Wars universe.References, cameos and familiar locations - there's plenty of that and the authors have carefully integrated it all into the canon. Overall, fans will be extremely pleased with the plot!

Played it originally on EA's Origin a few years ago when I had a subscription, but now doing NG+ on Steam after picking it up for $4 on sale to refresh myself on the story before playing Jedi Survivor. 

The game still looks, plays, and runs great. 

If you've never played it before then it's definitely worth picking up on sale. Regardless of your opinion on the state of Disney's Star Wars, Jedi Fallen Order is a worthy entry in the franchise with it's story and fun gameplay.

[i]“Trust only in the Force.” - Cere Junda[/i]
[u]Pros:[/u]
+ great cinematic presentation
+ good location design
+ puzzles were fun
+ difficulty can be changed anytime
[u]Cons:[/u]
- predictable story with an unsatisfying moment at the end
- occasional fps drops
- backtracking and zone reuse
- limited enemy variety
- exploration, while fun, feels unrewarding, with most of the rewards being skins for lightsaber/droid/ship

EA still sucks and I have no desire to use their software.

short_description: A galaxy-spanning adventure awaits in Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order, a 3rd person action-adventure title from Respawn. An abandoned Padawan must complete his training, develop new powerful Force abilities, and master the art of the lightsaber - all while staying one step ahead of the Empire.
